description: Fuel commodity role is the commodity role of fuels.

nodes.name: commodity role
description: A commodity role is a good role that inheres in something that is used in commerce and is exchangeable with other commodities of the same type.

nodes.name: commodity
description: A commodity is a good that bears the commodity role.

nodes.name: fuel commodity
description: A fuel commodity is a commodity that is a fuel.

nodes.name: markup
description: A markup is an economic value that indicates a virtual amount added to an assumed or historical price to predict a price in a different context.

nodes.name: markdown
description: A markdown is an economic value that indicates a virtual amount deducted from an assumed or historical price to predict a price in a different context.

nodes.name: inflation rate
description: Inflation rate is an economic value reprensenting the ratio between the monetary price for a good at two different points in time that equalises differences in monetary price levels between these two points in time.

nodes.name: exchange rate
description: The exchange rate is an economic value representing the ratio at which one currency can be exchanged for another.

nodes.name: purchasing power parity
description: Purchasing power parity is an economic value representing the ratio between currencies that equalises differences in monetary price levels between countries for the same set of goods.

nodes.name: due
description: A due is an economic value that represents a payment that an agent makes to belong to an organisation.

nodes.name: remuneration
description: A remuneration is an economic value that describes a financial compensation provided in exchange for services performed.

nodes.name: fee
description: A fee is an economic value that represents an amount of money paid for a  particular piece of work or for a particular right or service.

nodes.name: market revenue
description: Market revenue is an economic value that represents the income from a trade at a market exchange.

nodes.name: marginal cost
description: Marginal cost is the economic value that corresponds to the change in the total cost that arises when the quantity produced is incremented by one unit; that is, it is the cost of producing one more unit of a good.

nodes.name: cost
description: Cost is an economic value that describes the amount of money needed to buy, make, or do a thing.

nodes.name: gross domestic product
description: A gross domestic product is an economic value that represents the broadest measure of aggregate economic activity, measuring the total unduplicated market value of all final goods and services produced within a statistical area in a period.

nodes.name: gross value added
description: Gross value added is an economic value that is the value of goods and services produced in a sector of an economy, measuring that sector's contribution to gross domestic product (GDP). It is calculated as the monetary value of products and services produced, less the value of intermediate consumption.

nodes.name: discount rate
description: A discount rate is an economic value with the unit percent that refers to the interest rate used in discounted cash flow (DCF) analysis to determine the present value of future cash flows.

nodes.name: annual GDP growth
description: Annual GDP growth is an economic value that quantifies the difference between GDP in one year compared to the previous year.

nodes.name: pumped hydro energy
description: Pumped hydro energy is hydro energy that results from a water flow of pumped water.

nodes.name: typical period
description: A typical period is a time series that represents a couple of real time periods that have certain characteristics in common, e.g. seasonal specifications, weekly routines, etc. It doesn't refer to a real date. Typical periods are used to reduce computing time of energy system models.

nodes.name: weather time series
description: A weather time series is a time series that contains data about a specific meteorological year.

nodes.name: scenario time series
description: A scenario time series is a time series that contains data about a specific scenario year.

nodes.name: typical year
description: A typical year is a typical period with the duration of one year.

nodes.name: typical day
description: A typical day is a typical period with the duration of one day.

nodes.name: scenario year
description: A scenario year is a time step that has a duration of one year and is part of a scenario horizon.

nodes.name: time step
description: A time step is a one-dimensional temporal region that has a start time and an ending time and thus a finite duration.

nodes.name: scenario horizon
description: A scenario horizon is a time step that is under investigation and consists entirely of one or more scenario years.

nodes.name: meteorological year
description: A meteorological year is a time step in which meteorological data was collected and that has a duration of one year.

nodes.name: forced outage
description: A forced outage is an outage of an artificial object caused by a failure.

nodes.name: planned outage
description: A planned outage is an outage during which an artificial object is being maintained.

nodes.name: capacity premium
description: A capacity premium is a market premium that guarantees remuneration for reserving capacity of energy transformation units to be available for unexpected events.

nodes.name: tax
description: A tax is a levy whose returns are used by the government to finance expenditures for the common welfare.

nodes.name: system cost
description: System cost are total costs of a system.

nodes.name: levelised cost of electricity
description: Levelised cost of electricity are the net cost of converting energy to electricity / electric energy over the lifetime of an energy transformation unit. They are calculated considering all relevant costs including investment, operation, maintenance and fuel cost, etc.

nodes.name: variable cost
description: A variable cost is a cost that depends on an amount of goods or services.

nodes.name: investment cost
description: Investment costs are costs of a long-term commitment of financial resources in tangible or intangible assets.

nodes.name: fixed cost
description: A fixed cost is a cost for operation and maintenance that does not vary with the amount of goods or services produced.

nodes.name: delivery cost
description: A delivery cost is a cost for a product or service that refers to the total unit cost of a product or commodity delivered to a certain market, city or customer. It is normally composed of all associated transport costs and the unit cost of production for that product.

nodes.name: social cost of emission
description: Social cost of emission is the cost the society bears for an emission value.

nodes.name: temporal resolution
description: Temporal resolution is the resolution of a time series that indicates time-dependent the level of detail.

nodes.name: spatial resolution
description: Spatial resolution is the resolution of a georeferenced dataset that indicates the geographical level of detail.

nodes.name: space requirement
description: A space requirement is a two-dimensional spatial region that covers the area needed by an object or object aggregate.

nodes.name: protected area
description: A protected area is a two-dimensional spatial region recognised, dedicated and managed, through legal or other effective means, to achieve the long term conservation of nature with associated ecosystem services and cultural values.

nodes.name: operational space requirement
description: An operational space requirement is space requirement that covers the area needed by an artificial object in order to operate properly.

nodes.name: space requirement for construction
description: A space requirement for construction is space requirement of an artificial object that covers the area needed in order to construct an artificial object.

nodes.name: personal living space
description: A personal living space is a space requirement that one person uses for living.

nodes.name: square kilometer
description: An area unit which is equal to one million square meters or 10^[6] m^[2].

nodes.name: square meter
description: An area unit which is equal to an area enclosed by a square with sides each 1 meter long.

nodes.name: square centimeter
description: An area unit which is equal to one ten thousandth of a square meter or 10^[-4] m^[2].

nodes.name: square millimeter
description: An area unit which is equal to one millionth of a square meter or 10^[-6] m^[2].

nodes.name: square angstrom
description: An area unit which is equal to an area enclosed by a square with sides each 1 angstrom long.

nodes.name: square micrometer
description: An area unit which is equal to an area enclosed by a square with sides each 1 micrometer long.

nodes.name: hectare
description: An area unit which is equal to an area of 10,000 square meters. Equivalent to 2.471 acres.

nodes.name: perch
description: An area unit which is equal to an area of 25.292,852,64 square meters, or 1 square rod.

nodes.name: rood
description: An area unit which is equivalent to 1 furlong x 1 rod. This is equal to an area of 1,011.714,1056 square meters, or 40 square rods.

nodes.name: acre
description: An area unit which is equivalent to 1 furlong x 1 chain. This is equal to an area of 4,046.856,4224 square meters, or 43,500 square feet.

nodes.name: variable production cost
description: Variable costs are costs that depend on the amount of goods or services produced and which are paid by the producer.

nodes.name: fuel cost
description: A fuel cost is a variable cost that depends on the type and amount of fuel.

nodes.name: electricity cost
description: An electricity cost is a variable cost that depends on electricity price and amount.

nodes.name: anthropogenic
description: Anthropogenic is an origin of portions of matter or energies created by human activity.

nodes.name: biogenic
description: Biogenic is an origin of portions of matter made by or produced from life forms.

nodes.name: geogenic
description: Geogenic is an origin of portions of matter or energies that are the result of geological processes.

nodes.name: renewable
description: Renewable is an origin of energies that replenish on a human time scale.

nodes.name: social cost of carbon emission
description: Social cost of carbon emission is the cost the society bears for a greenhouse gas emission value.

nodes.name: carbon tax
description: Carbon tax is a tax for emitting CO2 or other greenhouse gases (measured in CO2 equivalent values).

nodes.name: equipment cost
description: Equipment cost is an investment cost for acquisition of the components and machinery including environmental facilities.

nodes.name: installation cost
description: Installation and development cost are investment costs incurred for setting up the installation.

nodes.name: grid connection cost
description: Grid connection costs are investment costs for establishing the grid connection from the energy generating device to point of connection to national grid.

nodes.name: property cost
description: A property cost is an investment cost arising from the acquisition of a property.

nodes.name: decommissioning cost
description: Decommissioning costs are investment costs arising from the decommissioning of a technological device at the end of its lifetime.

nodes.name: life time
description: A life time is a time span of an artificial object that measures the time during which the artificial object exists.

nodes.name: construction time
description: A construction time is a time span that measures the time that is needed to construct an artificial object.

nodes.name: decommissioning time
description: A decommissioning time is a time span that measures the time that is needed to decommission an artificial object.

nodes.name: delivery interval
description: A delivery interval is the duration between repeated deliveries of services or commodities.

nodes.name: amortisation time
description: An amortisation time is the time span in which the investment costs are refinanced from the annual profits and depreciation of the investment.

nodes.name: operational life time
description: An operational life time is the lifetime of an artificial object. It is measured from the end of construction time to the start of decommissioning time.

nodes.name: tangential proper part
description: A tangential proper part is a fiat object part of an entity which shares a boundary with that entity.

nodes.name: surface
description: A surface is a tangential proper part of an object that extends in two dimensions.

nodes.name: electrical energy amount value
description: An electrical energy amount value is an energy amount value that measures a quantity of electrical energy.

nodes.name: energy consumption value
description: An energy consumption value is an energy amount value that measures the energy consumption over a time span.

nodes.name: energy storage content
description: An energy storage content is an energy amount value that measures the quantity of energy stored in an energy storage object.

nodes.name: electricity import value
description: An electricity export value is an electrical energy amount value that measures the export of electrical energy.

nodes.name: electricity export value
description: An electricity import value is an electrical energy amount value that measures the import of electrical energy.

nodes.name: electricity import
description: Electricity import is the import of electrical energy.

nodes.name: electricity export
description: Electricity export is the export of electrical energy.

nodes.name: target driven scenario
description: A target driven scenario is a scenario that contains certain target constraints/ statements that in a possible future shall be realized. The path how the targets will be met is not predefined in the scenario.

nodes.name: explorative scenario
description: An explorative scenario is a scenario that contains certain constraints / statements regarding measures that are taken in the near future / today to explore where these measures will lead to in a later future. The later future is not predefined in the scenario.

nodes.name: policy scenario
description: A policy scenario is a scenario in which certain policy instruments or transformative measures and their impacts are assessed.

nodes.name: reference scenario
description: A reference scenario is a scenario that is used as a reference, e.g. in a scenario comparison. It has the reference role.

nodes.name: climate scenario
description: A climate scenario is a scenario that describes a possible future state of a climate system.

nodes.name: economic scenario
description: An economic scenario is a scenario that describes a possible future state of an economic system.

nodes.name: emission scenario
description: An emission scenario is a scenario that describes a possible emission trajectory.

nodes.name: energy scenario
description: An energy scenario is a scenario that describes a possible future state of an energy system.

nodes.name: compressed-air energy storage unit
description: A compressed-air energy storage unit is an energy storage unit that uses compressed air.

nodes.name: renewable energy share value
description: A renewable energy share value is a fraction value that quantifies a share of renewable energy (RE-share)

nodes.name: electrical energy share value
description: An electrical energy share value is a fraction value that quantifies the share of electrical energy (degree of electrification).

nodes.name: utilisation value
description: A utilisation value is a fraction value that describes the instantaneous share of a maximum value that is utilised.

nodes.name: without measures scenario
description: A without measures scenario (WOM) is a policy scenario that excludes all policy instruments and transformative measures which are planned, adopted or implemented.

nodes.name: with existing measures scenario
description: A with existing measures scenario (WEM) is a policy scenario that includes policy instruments and transformative measures that have been adopted and implemented.

nodes.name: with additional measures scenario
description: A with additional measures scenario (WAM) is a policy scenario that includes policy instruments and transformative measures which have been adopted and implemented to mitigate climate change or meet energy objectives, as well as policy instruments and transformative measures which are planned for that purpose.

nodes.name: greenhouse gas emission scenario
description: A greenhouse gas emission scenario is an emission scenario that describes a possible greenhouse gas emission trajectory.

nodes.name: CO2 emission scenario
description: A CO2 emission scenario is an emission scenario that describes a possible CO2 emission trajectory.

nodes.name: fossil
description: Fossil is a geogenic origin of portions of matter created from organic material by geological processes lasting thousands or millions of years.
editor_note: In real world, fossils are from biogenic origin some thousands or millions of years ago. However, this is irrelevant in the energy modelling domain.

nodes.name: synthetic
description: Synthetic is an anthropogenic origin of portions of matter created artificially by a chemical process.

nodes.name: energy autoproducer
description: An energy autoproducer is an organisational energy producer who produces electrical energy and/or heat wholly or partly for their own use as an activity which supports their primary activity.

nodes.name: main activity energy producer
description: A main activity energy producer is an organisational energy producer whose primary activity is electrical energy and/or heat production.

nodes.name: occurrent
editor_note: BFO 2 Reference: every occurrent that is not a temporal or spatiotemporal region is s-dependent on some independent continuant that is not a spatial region

BFO 2 Reference: s-dependence obtains between every process and its participants in the sense that, as a matter of necessity, this process could not have existed unless these or those participants existed also. A process may have a succession of participants at different phases of its unfolding. Thus there may be different players on the field at different times during the course of a football game; but the process which is the entire game s-depends_on all of these players nonetheless. Some temporal parts of this process will s-depend_on on only some of the players.
Occurrent doesn't have a closure axiom because the subclasses don't necessarily exhaust all possibilites. An example would be the sum of a process and the process boundary of another process.

Simons uses different terminology for relations of occurrents to regions: Denote the spatio-temporal location of a given occurrent e by 'spn[e]' and call this region its span. We may say an occurrent is at its span, in any larger region, and covers any smaller region. Now suppose we have fixed a frame of reference so that we can speak not merely of spatio-temporal but also of spatial regions (places) and temporal regions (times). The spread of an occurrent, (relative to a frame of reference) is the space it exactly occupies, and its spell is likewise the time it exactly occupies. We write 'spr[e]' and `spl[e]' respectively for the spread and spell of e, omitting mention of the frame.

nodes.name: temporal region
editor_note: Temporal region doesn't have a closure axiom because the subclasses don't exhaust all possibilites. An example would be the mereological sum of a temporal instant and a temporal interval that doesn't overlap the instant. In this case the resultant temporal region is neither 0-dimensional nor 1-dimensional

nodes.name: process boundary
description: p is a process boundary =Def. p is a temporal part of a process & p has no proper temporal parts. (axiom label in BFO2 Reference: [084-001])

nodes.name: immaterial entity
editor_note: BFO 2 Reference: Immaterial entities are divided into two subgroups:boundaries and sites, which bound, or are demarcated in relation, to material entities, and which can thus change location, shape and size and as their material hosts move or change shape or size (for example: your nasal passage; the hold of a ship; the boundary of Wales (which moves with the rotation of the Earth) [38, 7, 10

nodes.name: continuant fiat boundary
description: b is a continuant fiat boundary = Def. b is an immaterial entity that is of zero, one or two dimensions and does not include a spatial region as part. (axiom label in BFO2 Reference: [029-001])
editor_note: BFO 2 Reference: In BFO 1.1 the assumption was made that the external surface of a material entity such as a cell could be treated as if it were a boundary in the mathematical sense. The new document propounds the view that when we talk about external surfaces of material objects in this way then we are talking about something fiat. To be dealt with in a future version: fiat boundaries at different levels of granularity.More generally, the focus in discussion of boundaries in BFO 2.0 is now on fiat boundaries, which means: boundaries for which there is no assumption that they coincide with physical discontinuities. The ontology of boundaries becomes more closely allied with the ontology of regions.

BFO 2 Reference: a continuant fiat boundary is a boundary of some material entity (for example: the plane separating the Northern and Southern hemispheres; the North Pole), or it is a boundary of some immaterial entity (for example of some portion of airspace). Three basic kinds of continuant fiat boundary can be distinguished (together with various combination kinds [29

Continuant fiat boundary doesn't have a closure axiom because the subclasses don't necessarily exhaust all possibilites. An example would be the mereological sum of two-dimensional continuant fiat boundary and a one dimensional continuant fiat boundary that doesn't overlap it. The situation is analogous to temporal and spatial regions.

nodes.name: energy system
description: An energy system is a supply system of spatially extended linked energy sources and sinks.

nodes.name: primary energy carrier mining
description: Primary energy carrier mining is a primary energy production that recovers non-renewable energy carriers from its natural site.

nodes.name: primary energy carrier harvest
description: Primary energy carrier harvest is a primary energy production that collects solid biomass from its natural site.

nodes.name: exogenous data
description: Exogenous data is a data item whose quantity value is determined outside of a model and is imposed on a model.

nodes.name: data about an ontology part
description: Data about an ontology part is a data item about a part of an ontology, for example a term

nodes.name: start time
description: A start time is a zero-dimensional temporal region that indicates the beginning of a one-dimensional temporal region.

nodes.name: ending time
description: An ending time is a zero-dimensional temporal region that indicates the end of a one-dimensional temporal region.

nodes.name: time stamp
description: A time stamp is a zero-dimensional temporal region that is used to describe a time step.

nodes.name: delivery time point
description: A delivery time point is a zero-dimensional temporal region expressing the point in time when goods that have been bought arrive at the place where they are wanted.

nodes.name: one-dimensional temporal region
editor_note: BFO 2 Reference: A temporal interval is a special kind of one-dimensional temporal region, namely one that is self-connected (is without gaps or breaks).

nodes.name: delivery time
description: Delivery time is a one-dimensional temporal region expressing the amount of time that it takes for goods that have been bought to arrive at the place where they are wanted.

nodes.name: trader
description: A trader is a market participant that engages in the transfer of financial assets in any financial market on behalf of a client or a financial services provider.

nodes.name: price request
description: A price request is a request in which an agent asks another agent for a price.

nodes.name: fuel-powered electricity generation process
description: A fuel-powered electricity generation process is an electricity generation process that converts chemical energy from a combustion fuel to electrical energy. It causes some emission.

nodes.name: kilojoule
description: An energy unit which is equal to 1,000 joules.

nodes.name: megajoule
description: An energy unit which is equal to 1,000,000 joules.

nodes.name: gigajoule
description: An energy unit which is equal to 10^9 joules.

nodes.name: terajoule
description: An energy unit which is equal to 10^12 joules.

nodes.name: petajoule
description: An energy unit which is equal to 10^15 joules.

nodes.name: exajoule
description: An energy unit which is equal to 10^18 joules.

nodes.name: megawatt-hour
description: An energy unit which is equal to 1,000,000 watt-hours.

nodes.name: terawatt-hour
description: An energy unit which is equal to 10^12 watt-hours.

nodes.name: petawatt-hour
description: An energy unit which is equal to 10^15 watt-hours.

nodes.name: gigawatt-hour
description: An energy unit which is equal to 10^9 watt-hours.

nodes.name: ton of oil equivalent
description: A ton of oil equivalent is an energy unit which is equal to the amount of energy released by burning one metric ton of crude oil with a certain net calorific value. That is defined as 41.868 gigajoules or 11.63 megawatt-hours.

nodes.name: kilo ton of oil equivalent
description: A kilo ton of oil equivalent is an energy unit which is equal to 1,000 tons of oil equivalent.

nodes.name: million ton of oil equivalent
description: A million ton of oil equivalent is an energy unit which is equal to 1,000,000 tons of oil equivalent.

nodes.name: ton of coal equivalent
description: A ton of coal equivalent is an energy unit which is equal to the amount of energy released by burning one metric ton of coal with a certain net calorific value. That is defined as 0.7 tons of oil equivalent (toe) and thus equals 29.3076 gigajoules or 8.141 megawatt-hours.

nodes.name: kilo ton of coal equivalent
description: A kilo ton of coal equivalent is an energy unit which is equal to 1,000 tons of coal equivalent.

nodes.name: million ton of coal equivalent
description: A million ton of coal equivalent is an energy unit which is equal to 1,000,000 tons of coal equivalent.

nodes.name: joule
description: An energy unit which is equal to the energy required when a force of 1 newton moves an object 1 meter in the direction of the force.

nodes.name: watt-hour
description: An energy unit which is equal to the amount of electrical energy equivalent to a one-watt load drawing power for one hour.

nodes.name: kilowatt-hour
description: An energy unit which is equal to 1,000 watt-hours.

nodes.name: electronvolt
description: A non-SI unit of energy (eV) defined as the energy acquired by a single unbound electron when it passes through an electrostatic potential difference of one volt. An electronvolt is equal to 1.602 176 53(14) x 10^-19 J.

nodes.name: slug
description: An imperial gravitational unit which is equivalent to a mass that accelerates by 1ft/s² when a force of one pound (lbf) is exerted on it.

nodes.name: final energy consumption
description: Final energy consumption is an energy consumption value accounting for the energy delivered to and consumed by end users.

nodes.name: gross inland energy consumption
description: Gross inland energy consumption is an energy consumption value accounting for the total consumption of energy in a spatial region (e.g. a country).

nodes.name: primary energy consumption
description: Primary energy consumption is an energy consumption value accounting for the total consumption of energy in a spatial region excluding the non-energetic use of fuels.
editor_note: Primary energy consumption covers consumption of the energy sector itself, losses during transformation (for example, from oil or gas into electricity) and distribution of energy, and the final consumption by end users. It excludes energy carriers used for non-energy purposes (such as petroleum not used not for combustion but for producing plastics).

nodes.name: gross national electricity consumption
description: Gross national electricity consumption is an energy consumption value measuring the consumption of electrical energy in a spatial region (e.g. a country), including gross electricity generation plus electricity imports, minus electricity exports. It is part of the gross inland energy consumption.

nodes.name: funder
description: A funder is a sponsor that supports by giving money.

nodes.name: public funder
description: A public funder is a funder that gives public money.

nodes.name: private funder
description: A private funder is a funder that gives private money.

nodes.name: steam
description: Steam is water that has a gaseous state of matter.

nodes.name: private transport
description: A private transport is a passenger transport in which people use their own vehicle for movement e.g. bicycle, motorcycle and cars.

nodes.name: public transport
description: A public transport is a passenger transport in which a number of passengers share a common vehicle.

nodes.name: cross-checking against other models
description: Cross-checking against other models is a validation where a model gets cross-checked against other models of the domain.

nodes.name: checking against measurements
description: Checking against measurements is a validation where something gets checked by using relevant measurements.

nodes.name: checking against empirical data
description: Checking against empirical data is a validation where something gets checked against empirical data.

nodes.name: demand
description: A demand is a realizable entity that is characterised by a person, organisation or object needing it for a specific purpose.

nodes.name: flow potential
description: A flow potential is a potential of an input or output of a process, per time unit.

nodes.name: stock potential
description: A stock potential is a potential of the stock of a source or sink.

nodes.name: theoretical flow potential
description: A theoretical flow potential is a type of flow potential that identifies the physical upper limit of an input or output of a process in a spatial region of reference per unit time.

nodes.name: technological flow potential
description: A technological flow potential is a type of a flow potential derived from a theoretical flow potential, taking account of the annual efficiency of the respective conversion technology and the additional restrictions regarding the area that is realistically available for energy generation.

nodes.name: economic flow potential
description: An economic flow potential is a type of flow potential that identifies the proportion of the technological potential that can be utilised economically (based on economic boundary conditions).

nodes.name: developable flow potential
description: A developable flow potential is a type of flow potential that describes the fraction of the economic potential that can be developed under realistic conditions (regulations, environmental and social restrictions).

nodes.name: sustainable flow potential
description: A sustainable flow potential is a type of flow potential that takes into account all aspects of sustainability, which usually requires careful consideration and evaluation of different ecological and socio-economic aspects. The differentiation of the sustainable potential is blurred, since ecological aspects may already have been considered for the technological or economic potential, depending on the author.

nodes.name: theoretical stock potential
description: A theoretical stock potential is a type of stock potential that identifies the physical upper limit of a stock of a source or sink in a spatial region of reference.

nodes.name: technological stock potential
description: A technological stock potential is a type of a stock potential derived from a theoretical stock potential, taking account of the annual efficiency of the respective conversion technology and the additional restrictions regarding the area that is realistically available for energy generation.

nodes.name: economic stock potential
description: An economic stock potential is a type of stock potential that identifies the proportion of the technological potential that can be utilised economically (based on economic boundary conditions).

nodes.name: developable stock potential
description: A developable stock potential is a type of stock potential that describes the fraction of the economic potential that can be developed under realistic conditions (regulations, environmental and social restrictions).

nodes.name: sustainable stock potential
description: A sustainable stock potential is a type of stock potential that takes into account all aspects of sustainability, which usually requires careful consideration and evaluation of different ecological and socio-economic aspects. The differentiation of the sustainable potential is blurred, since ecological aspects may already have been considered for the technological or economic potential, depending on the author.

nodes.name: greenhouse gas emission value
description: A greenhouse gas emission value is an emission value that quantifies the output of a greenhouse gas emission process.

nodes.name: carbon dioxide emission value
description: A CO2 emission value is greenhouse gas emission value that quantifies the output of a CO2 emission process.

nodes.name: carbon dioxide equivalent quantity
description: A carbon dioxide equivalent quantity is a greenhouse gas emission value that quantifies the combined effect of all emitted greenhouse gases by giving an equivalent amount of CO2 which would have the same effect on the climate.

nodes.name: artificial ambient thermal energy
description: Artificial ambient thermal energy is ambient thermal energy that has an anthropogenic origin.

nodes.name: block size
description: Block size is the declared net capacity of a power generating unit.

nodes.name: declared net capacity
description: Declared net capacity is a power capacity stating the maximum power a power generating unit or a power plant can deliver to the electrical grid. It equals the sum of the rated powers of all plant generators minus all power used internally within the plant.

nodes.name: conventional trader
description: A trader that trades the power of fossil fuel power plants.

nodes.name: demand trader
description: A demand trader is a trader that deals specifically with energy demand.

nodes.name: direct marketer
description: A direct marketer is a trader who is the relay between the energy exchange and power plant operators.

nodes.name: hydrogen fuel cell
description: A hydrogen fuel cell is a fuel cell that uses hydrogen.

nodes.name: yield profile
description: A yield profile is a generation time series of a particular renewable power plant.

nodes.name: energy demand
description: Energy demand is a demand for energy.

nodes.name: vehicle operational mode
description: A vehicle operational mode is a realizable entity that determines how a vehicle is operating.

nodes.name: primary control
description: A primary control is a frequency control that is decentralised and automated. It reacts within seconds to frequency deviations caused by electricity supply and demand imbalances.

nodes.name: secondary control
description: A secondary control is a frequency control that is centralised and automated. It refers to the control area of one transmission system operator. Secondary control succeeds primary control and operates for several minutes.

nodes.name: tertiary control
description: A tertiary control is a frequency control that is either automated or manual. It takes over from secondary control to equalise electricity supply and demand imbalances that last for more than 15 minutes.

nodes.name: power rating
description: Power rating is a power capacity stating the maximum power an energy converting component can convert.

nodes.name: nameplate capacity
description: Nameplate capacity is the power capacity stating the maximum power an artificial object, e.g. a power generating unit or a power plant, can generate, and the sum of the power ratings of all energy converting component of that power plant.

nodes.name: urban population
description: An urban population is a population living in urban areas, as defined by national statistical offices.

nodes.name: rural population
description: A rural population is a population living in rural areas, as defined by national statistical offices.

nodes.name: labour force
description: The labour force is the population of people ages 15 and older who supply labour to the production of goods and services.  It includes people who are currently employed and people who are unemployed but seeking work as well as first-time job-seekers.

nodes.name: working age population
description: The working age population is the population of people aged 15 to 65.

nodes.name: net capacity factor
description: A net capacity factor is a utilisation value that is calculated by dividing the net electricity generation over a given time step by the declared net capacity times the length of this time step.
editor_note: A net capacity factor is typically calculated for a year but other time steps (e.g. month or day) are possible.

nodes.name: energy storage level
description: An energy storage level is a utilisation value that measures the utilisation/usage/exploitation of energy storage capacity.

nodes.name: non-metallic mineral
description: A non-metallic mineral is a mineral that does not contain any metallic content within themselves. It is the physical output of an industrial process and has a commodity role.
editor_note: Some examples for non-metallic minerals are ceramic, glass, clay or gypsum.

nodes.name: steel
description: Steel is a metal that consists mainly of iron and up to 2.14 % of carbon; other elements may be present. It has a solid normal state of matter. It has a solid normal state of matter. It is the physical output of an industrial process and has a commodity role.

nodes.name: non-ferrous metal
description: A non-ferrous metal is a metal that does not contain a significant amount of iron in its chemical composition. It is the physical output of an industrial process and has a commodity role.

nodes.name: data file format
description: A file format is a data format that describes how data is structured in a file.

nodes.name: text file format
description: A text file format is a file format that is structured as a sequence of lines of electronic text.

nodes.name: binary file format
description: A binary file format is a file format that is not a text format.

nodes.name: delimiter separated file format
description: A delimiter separated file format is a text file format that uses delimiter-separated values (also DSV) to store two-dimensional arrays of data by separating the values in each row with specific delimiter characters.

nodes.name: source code file format
description: A source code file format is a text file format that is source code in a programming language.

nodes.name: comma separated file format
description: A comma separated file format is a delimiter separated file format that uses comma (,) as delimiter.

nodes.name: industrial waste thermal energy
description: Industrial waste thermal energy is waste thermal energy that is energy output of some industrial process.

nodes.name: heat transfer unit
description: A heat transfer unit is a heat generating unit that contains a heat exchanger and not a heater.

nodes.name: solar heat unit
description: A solar heat unit is a heat generating unit that has a solar collector.

nodes.name: geothermal heat unit
description: A geothermal heat unit is a heat transfer unit that uses geothermal energy as source.

nodes.name: geothermal heat plant
description: A geothermal heat plant is a heat plant that has geothermal heat units as parts.

nodes.name: tube collector
description: A tube collector is a solar thermal collector that consists of tubes.

nodes.name: flat-plate collector
description: A flat-plate collector is a solar thermal collector that consists of flat-plates.

nodes.name: combined cycle electricity generation process
description: A combined cycle electricity generation process is a fuel-powered electricity generation process in which a gas turbine process is followed by an steam-electric process.

nodes.name: chemical heat storage object
description: A chemical heat storage object is a thermo-chemical heat storage object that stores thermal energy by using the chemical binding energy in an endotherm reaction.

nodes.name: sorption heat storage object
description: A sorption heat storage object is a thermo-chemical heat storage object that stores thermal energy by using desorption.

nodes.name: sensible fluid heat storage object
description: A sensible fluid heat storage object is a sensible heat storage that uses fluids (like water, oil, …) to store thermal energy.

nodes.name: sensible solid heat storage object
description: A sensible solid heat storage object is a sensible heat storage that uses solid materials (like bulk goods, powder, …) to store thermal energy.

nodes.name: evaporation
description: Evaporation is a phase transition from a liquid medium to their gaseous state.

nodes.name: melting
description: Melting is a phase transition from a solid medium to their liquid state.

nodes.name: latent solid-fluid heat storage object
description: A latent solid-fluid heat storage object is a latent heat storage object that stores thermal energy by converting solid materials to their liquid equivalent i.e. melting the material.

nodes.name: latent fluid-gaseous heat storage object
description: A latent fluid-gaseous heat storage object is a latent heat storage object that stores thermal energy by converting liquid materials to their gaseous equivalent i.e. evaporating the material.

nodes.name: passenger-kilometre
description: Passenger-kilometre is a transport performance unit for the accumulated transport distance of people where one passenger-kilometre equals the transport distance of 1 km for one person.

nodes.name: ton-kilometre
description: Ton-kilometre is a transport performance unit for the accumulated transport distance of goods where one ton-kilometre equals the transport distance of 1 km for one ton of goods.

nodes.name: vehicle-kilometre
description: Vehicle-kilometre is a transport performance unit for the accumulated transport distance of the used vehicles themselves where one vehicle-kilometre equals the transport distance of 1 km for one vehicle.

nodes.name: gas vehicle
description: A gas vehicle is an internal combustion vehicle that has only a gas engine as a motor for propulsion.

nodes.name: gasoline vehicle
description: A gasoline vehicle is an internal combustion vehicle that has only a gasoline engine as motor for propulsion.
editor_note: The term gasoline was chosen as this term is more often used in energy modelling and energy statistics. This is a deliberate deviation from the convention of British English spelling in the OEO.

nodes.name: diesel vehicle
description: A diesel vehicle is an internal combustion vehicle that has only a diesel engine as motor for propulsion.

nodes.name: liquefied petroleum gas vehicle
description: A liquefied petroleum gas vehicle is a gas vehicle that uses liquefied petroleum gas as fuel.

nodes.name: compressed gas vehicle
description: A compressed gas vehicle is a gas vehicle that uses a compressed gas fuel.

nodes.name: liquefied natural gas vehicle
description: A liquefied natural gas vehicle is a gas vehicle that uses liquefied natural gas as fuel.

nodes.name: gas engine
description: A gas engine is an internal combustion engine that uses a gaseous combustion fuel.

nodes.name: gasoline engine
description: A gasoline engine is an internal combustion engine that uses a gasoline fuel.
editor_note: The term gasoline was chosen as this term is more often used in energy modelling and energy statistics. This is a deliberate deviation from the convention of British English spelling in the OEO.

nodes.name: diesel engine
description: A diesel engine is an internal combustion engine that uses a diesel fuel.

nodes.name: compressed gas engine
description: A compressed gas engine is a gas engine that uses a compressed gas fuel.

nodes.name: compressed gas fuel role
description: A compressed gas fuel role is a fuel role that expresses that a portion of matter can be used in a compressed gas engine.

nodes.name: gasoline fuel role
description: A gasoline fuel role is a fuel role that expresses that a portion of matter can be used in a gasoline engine.
editor_note: The term gasoline was chosen as this term is more often used in energy modelling and energy statistics. This is a deliberate deviation from the convention of British English spelling in the OEO.

nodes.name: diesel fuel role
description: A diesel fuel role is a fuel role that expresses that a portion of matter can be used in a diesel engine.

nodes.name: compressed biomethane
description: Compressed biomethane is biomethane that has been compressed.

nodes.name: compressed synthetic methane
description: Compressed synthetic methane is synthetic methane that has been compressed.

nodes.name: road network
description: A road network is a transport network that enables transport on roads.

nodes.name: rail network
description: A rail network is a transport network that enables transport on rails.

nodes.name: waterway network
description: A waterway network is a transport network that enables transport on water.

nodes.name: aviation network
description: An aviation network is a transport network that enables air transport.

nodes.name: road
description: A road is a transport network component with an artificial surface that allows transport for road vehicles.

nodes.name: bridge
description: A bridge is a transport network component that spans a physical obstacle without blocking the way underneath.

nodes.name: tunnel
description: A tunnel is a transport network component that is built through a certain environment (e.g. a mountain or water) and allows to pass through that environment.

nodes.name: railway
description: A railway is a transport network component that can only be used by trains.

nodes.name: canal
description: A canal is a transport network component that is an artificially created waterway.

nodes.name: transport hub
description: A transport hub is a transport network component that allows the exchange of people and/or goods.

nodes.name: train station
description: A train station is a transport hub for trains.

nodes.name: bus station
description: A bus station is a transport hub for busses.

nodes.name: port
description: A port is a transport hub for ships.

nodes.name: airport
description: An airport is a transport hub for airplanes.

nodes.name: freight train station
description: A freight train station is a train station for the exchange of goods.

nodes.name: passenger train station
description: A passenger train station is a train station for the exchange of passengers.

nodes.name: freight port
description: A freight port is a port for the exchange of goods.

nodes.name: passenger port
description: A passenger port is a port for the exchange of passengers.

nodes.name: fuel transport
description: Fuel transport is the freight transport of fuels.

nodes.name: combustion fuel transport
description: Combustion fuel transport is the fuel transport of combustion fuels.

nodes.name: vehicle charging station
description: A vehicle charging station is an electricity grid component that transfers electrical energy into the traction battery of a battery electric vehicle.

nodes.name: fuel supply system
description: A fuel supply system is an energy system covering the distribution of fuels.

nodes.name: diesel car
description: A diesel car is a car that has only a diesel engine as motor for propulsion and thus is also a diesel vehicle.

nodes.name: gasoline car
description: A gasoline car is a car that has only a gasoline engine as motor for propulsion and thus is also a gasoline vehicle.

nodes.name: battery electric car
description: A battery electric car is a car that has an electric traction motor and a traction battery and thus is also a battery electric vehicle.

nodes.name: fuel cell electric car
description: A fuel cell electric car is a car that has an electric traction motor and uses electrical energy from a fuel cell and thus is also a fuel cell electric vehicle.

nodes.name: compressed gas car
description: A compressed gas car is a car that uses compressed gas in a gas engine for propulsion and thus is also a compressed gas vehicle.

nodes.name: liquefied petroleum gas car
description: A liquefied petroleum gas car is a car that uses liquefied petroleum gas in a gas engine for propulsion and thus is also a liquefied petroleum gas vehicle.

nodes.name: plug-in hybrid electric car
description: A plug-in hybrid electric car is a car that can switch between an electric traction motor and an internal combustion engine for propulsion and thus is also a plug-in hybrid electric vehicle.

nodes.name: diesel truck
description: A diesel truck is a truck that has only a diesel engine as motor for propulsion and thus is also a diesel vehicle.

nodes.name: battery electric truck
description: A battery electric truck is a truck that has an electric traction motor and a traction battery and thus is also a battery electric vehicle.

nodes.name: fuel cell electric truck
description: A fuel cell electric truck is a truck that has an electric traction motor and uses electrical energy from a fuel cell and thus is also a fuel cell electric vehicle.

nodes.name: compressed gas truck
description: A compressed gas truck is a truck that uses compressed gas in a gas engine for propulsion and thus is also a compressed gas vehicle.

nodes.name: liquefied natural gas truck
description: A liquefied natural gas truck is a truck that uses liquefied natural gas in a gas engine for propulsion and thus is also a liquefied natural gas vehicle.

nodes.name: fuel tank
description: A fuel tank is a tank that stores a combustion fuel.

nodes.name: hydrogen station
description: A hydrogen station is a filling station that transfers hydrogen.

nodes.name: hydrogen transport
description: Hydrogen transport is the combustion fuel transport of hydrogen.

nodes.name: electricity demand
description: Electricity demand is the energy demand for electricity.

nodes.name: fuel demand
description: Fuel demand is the energy demand for fuel.

nodes.name: charging
description: Charging is an electrical energy transfer where the transferred energy is stored in a battery.

nodes.name: bidirectional vehicle charging station
description: A bidirectional vehicle charging station is a vehicle charging station that can also feed electrical energy from the traction battery back into the electricity grid.

nodes.name: economic life time
description: An economic life time is the operational life time during which an artificial object is profitable to the owner.

nodes.name: OEP study factsheet
description: An OEP study factsheet is an study factsheet hosted on the Open Energy Platform. It is used to access the Open Energy Knowledge Graph (OEKG).

nodes.name: scenario study
description: A scenario study is a study that investigates one or more scenarios.

nodes.name: entity
editor_note: BFO 2 Reference: In all areas of empirical inquiry we encounter general terms of two sorts. First are general terms which refer to universals or types:animaltuberculosissurgical procedurediseaseSecond, are general terms used to refer to groups of entities which instantiate a given universal but do not correspond to the extension of any subuniversal of that universal because there is nothing intrinsic to the entities in question by virtue of which they – and only they – are counted as belonging to the given group. Examples are: animal purchased by the Emperortuberculosis diagnosed on a Wednesdaysurgical procedure performed on a patient from Stockholmperson identified as candidate for clinical trial #2056-555person who is signatory of Form 656-PPVpainting by Leonardo da VinciSuch terms, which represent what are called ‘specializations’ in [81

Entity doesn't have a closure axiom because the subclasses don't necessarily exhaust all possibilites. For example Werner Ceusters 'portions of reality' include 4 sorts, entities (as BFO construes them), universals, configurations, and relations. It is an open question as to whether entities as construed in BFO will at some point also include these other portions of reality. See, for example, 'How to track absolutely everything' at http://www.referent-tracking.com/_RTU/papers/CeustersICbookRevised.pdf

nodes.name: zero-dimensional continuant fiat boundary
editor_note: zero dimension continuant fiat boundaries are not spatial points. Considering the example 'the quadripoint where the boundaries of Colorado, Utah, New Mexico, and Arizona meet' : There are many frames in which that point is zooming through many points in space. Whereas, no matter what the frame, the quadripoint is always in the same relation to the boundaries of Colorado, Utah, New Mexico, and Arizona.

nodes.name: curation status specification
description: The curation status of the term. The allowed values come from an enumerated list of predefined terms. See the specification of these instances for more detailed definitions of each enumerated value.
editor_note: Better to represent curation as a process with parts and then relate labels to that process (in IAO meeting)

nodes.name: obsolescence reason specification
description: The reason for which a term has been deprecated. The allowed values come from an enumerated list of predefined terms. See the specification of these instances for more detailed definitions of each enumerated value.
editor_note: The creation of this class has been inspired in part by Werner Ceusters' paper, Applying evolutionary terminology auditing to the Gene Ontology.

nodes.name: denotator type
description: A denotator type indicates how a term should be interpreted from an ontological perspective.

nodes.name: ontology module
editor_note: I have placed this under 'data about an ontology part', but this can be discussed. I think this is OK if 'part' is interpreted reflexively, as an ontology module is the whole ontology rather than part of it.

nodes.name: written name
description: A textual entity that denotes a particular in reality.

nodes.name: base ontology module
description: An ontology module that comprises only of asserted axioms local to the ontology, excludes import directives, and excludes axioms or declarations from external ontologies.

nodes.name: editors ontology module
description: An ontology module that is intended to be directly edited, typically managed in source control, and typically not intended for direct consumption by end-users.

nodes.name: main release ontology module
description: An ontology module that is intended to be the primary release product and the one consumed by the majority of tools.
editor_note: TODO: Add logical axioms that state that a main release ontology module is derived from (directly or indirectly) an editors module

nodes.name: bridge ontology module
description: An ontology module that consists entirely of axioms that connect or bridge two distinct ontology modules. For example, the Uberon-to-ZFA bridge module.

nodes.name: subset ontology module
description: An ontology module that is extracted from a main ontology module and includes only a subset of entities or axioms.

nodes.name: reasoned ontology module
description: An ontology module that contains axioms generated by a reasoner. The generated axioms are typically direct SubClassOf axioms, but other possibilities are available.

nodes.name: generated ontology module
description: An ontology module that is automatically generated, for example via a SPARQL query or via template and a CSV.
editor_note: TODO: Add axioms (using PROV-O?) that indicate this is the output-of some reasoning process

nodes.name: import ontology module
description: A subset ontology module that is intended to be imported from another ontology.
editor_note: TODO: add axioms that indicate this is the output of a module extraction process.

nodes.name: curation subset ontology module
description: A subset ontology that is intended as a whitelist for curators using the ontology. Such a subset will exclude classes that curators should not use for curation.

nodes.name: analysis subset ontology module
description: An ontology module that is intended for usage in analysis or discovery applications.

nodes.name: single layer subset ontology module
description: A subset ontology that is largely comprised of a single layer or strata in an ontology class hierarchy. The purpose is typically for rolling up for visualization. The classes in the layer need not be disjoint.

nodes.name: exclusion subset ontology module
description: A subset of an ontology that is intended to be excluded for some purpose. For example, a blacklist of classes.

nodes.name: species subset ontology module
description: A subset ontology that is crafted to either include or exclude a taxonomic grouping of species.

nodes.name: external import ontology module
description: An imported ontology module that is derived from an external ontology. Derivation methods include the OWLAPI SLME approach.

nodes.name: template generated ontology module
description: An ontology module that is automatically generated from a template specification and fillers for slots in that template.

nodes.name: obo basic subset ontology module
description:
A subset ontology that is designed for basic applications to continue to make certain simplifying assumptions; many of these simplifying assumptions were based on the initial version of the Gene Ontology, and have become enshrined in many popular and useful tools such as term enrichment tools.

Examples of such assumptions include: traversing the ontology graph ignoring relationship types using a naive algorithm will not lead to cycles (i.e. the ontology is a DAG); every referenced term is declared in the ontology (i.e. there are no dangling clauses).

An ontology is OBO Basic if and only if it has the following characteristics:
DAG
Unidirectional
No Dangling Clauses
Fully Asserted
Fully Labeled
No equivalence axioms
Singly labeled edges
No qualifier lists
No disjointness axioms
No owl-axioms header
No imports

nodes.name: ontology module subsetted by OWL profile
luminous intensity unit
description: A unit which is a standard measure of the wavelength-weighted power emitted by a light source in a particular direction.

nodes.name: luminance unit
description: A unit which is a standard measure of the luminous intensity impinging on a given area.

nodes.name: illuminance unit
description: A unit which is a standard measure of the luminous flux incident on a unit area.

nodes.name: luminous flux unit
description: A unit which is a standard measure of the flow of radiant energy.

nodes.name: irradiance unit
description: A unit which is a standard measure of the power of electromagnetic radiation at a surface, per unit area.

nodes.name: radiant intensity unit
description: A unit which is a standard measure of the intensity of electromagnetic radiation.

nodes.name: radiance unit
description: A unit which is a standard measure of the power of electromagnetic radiation through space or through a material medium in the form of electromagnetic waves.

nodes.name: relative light unit
description: A derived unit which is a measure of relative light intensity, as typically measured by a luminometer, spectrophotometer, or fluorimeter in biological research applications.

nodes.name: meter
description: A length unit which is equal to the length of the path traveled by light in vacuum during a time interval of 1/299 792 458 of a second.

nodes.name: centimeter
description: A length unit which is equal to one hundredth of a meter or 10^[-2] m.

nodes.name: millimeter
description: A length unit which is equal to one thousandth of a meter or 10^[-3] m.

nodes.name: micrometer
description: A length unit which is equal to one millionth of a meter or 10^[-6] m.

nodes.name: nanometer
description: A length unit which is equal to one thousandth of one millionth of a meter or 10^[-9] m.

nodes.name: angstrom
description: A length unit which is equal to 10 [-10] m.

nodes.name: picometer
description: A length unit which is equal to 10^[-12] m.

nodes.name: centiMorgan
description: A unit used to express distances on a genetic map. In genetic mapping, distances between markers are determined by measuring the rate of meoitic recombination between them, which increases proportionately with the distance separating them. A cM is defined as the length of an interval in which there is a 1% probability of recombination. On the average, 1 cM is roughly equivalent to 1 megabase (Mb) of DNA, although this can vary widely due to hot and cold spots of recombination.

nodes.name: centiRay
description: A unit of genetic map distance defined corresponding to an interval in which there is a 1% probability of X-irradiation induced breakage. To be completely specified, the unit must be qualified by the radiation in dosage in rads (e.g. cR8000), because this determines the actual breakage probability.

nodes.name: inch
description: A length unit which is equal to 0.0254 metres.

nodes.name: thou
description: A length unit which is equal to 0.0254 millimetres.

nodes.name: foot
description: A length unit which is equal to 0.3048 metres, or 12 inches.

nodes.name: yard
description: A length unit which is equal to 0.9144 metres, or 3 feet.

nodes.name: chain
description: A length unit which is equal to 20.1168 metres, 66 feet, or 22 yards.

nodes.name: furlong
description: A length unit which is equal to 20,116.8 metres, 660 feet, or 10 chains.

nodes.name: mile
description: A length unit which is equal to 1,609.344 metres, or 8 furlongs.

nodes.name: league
description: A length unit which is equal to 3 miles, or 4,828.032 metres

nodes.name: maritime length unit
description: A maritime length unit is one used primarily at sea.

nodes.name: second
description: A time unit which is equal to the duration of 9 192 631 770 periods of the radiation corresponding to the transition between the two hyperfine levels of the ground state of the caesium 133 atom.

nodes.name: ampere
description: An electric current unit which is equal to the constant current which, if maintained in two straight parallel conductors of infinite length, of negligible circular cross-section, and placed 1 m apart in vacuum, would produce between these conductors a force equal to 2 x 10^[-7] newton per meter of length.

nodes.name: kelvin
description: A thermodynamic temperature unit which is equal to the fraction 1/273.16 of the thermodynamic temperature of the triple point of water.

nodes.name: mole
description: A substance unit which is equal to the amount of substance of a molecular system which contains as many elementary entities as there are atoms in 0.012 kilogram of carbon 12.

nodes.name: candela
description: A luminous intensity unit which equal to the luminous intensity, in a given direction, of a source that emits monochromatic radiation of frequency 540 x 1012 hertz and that has a radiant intensity in that direction of 1/683 watt per steradian.

nodes.name: millisecond
description: A time unit which is equal to one thousandth of a second or 10^[-3] s.

nodes.name: microsecond
description: A time unit which is equal to one millionth of a second or 10^[-6] s.

nodes.name: picosecond
description: A time unit which is equal to 10^[-12] s.

nodes.name: minute
description: A time unit which is equal to 60 seconds.

nodes.name: hour
description: A time unit which is equal to 3600 seconds or 60 minutes.

nodes.name: day
description: A time unit which is equal to 24 hours.

nodes.name: week
description: A time unit which is equal to 7 days.

nodes.name: month
description: A time unit which is approximately equal to the length of time of one of cycle of the moon's phases which in science is taken to be equal to 30 days.

nodes.name: year
description: A time unit which is equal to 12 months which in science is taken to be equal to 365.25 days.

nodes.name: nanosecond
description: A time unit which is equal to one thousandth of one millionth of a second or 10^[-9] s.

nodes.name: century
description: A time unit which is equal to 100 years.

nodes.name: half life
description: A time unit which represents the period over which the activity or concentration of a specified chemical or element falls to half its original activity or concentration.

nodes.name: milliampere
description: An electric current unit current which is equal to one thousandth of an ampere or 10^[-3] A.

nodes.name: microampere
description: An electric current unit current which is equal to one millionth of an ampere or 10^[-6] A.

nodes.name: degree Celsius
description: A temperature unit which is equal to one kelvin degree. However, they have their zeros at different points. The centigrade scale has its zero at 273.15 K.

nodes.name: degree Fahrenheit
description: A temperature unit which is equal to 5/9ths of a kelvin. Negative 40 degrees Fahrenheit is equal to negative 40 degrees Celsius.

nodes.name: micromole
description: A substance unit equal to a millionth of a mol or 10^[-6] mol.

nodes.name: millimole
description: A substance unit equal to a thousandth of a mol or 10^[-3] mol.

nodes.name: nanomole
description: A substance unit equal to one thousandth of one millionth of a mole or 10^[-9] mol.

nodes.name: picomole
description: A substance unit equal to 10^[-12] mol.

nodes.name: femtomole
description: A substance unit equal to 10^[-15] mol.

nodes.name: attomole
description: A substance unit equal to 10^[-18] mol.

nodes.name: mass density unit
description: A density unit which is a standard measure of the mass of a substance in a given volume.

nodes.name: area density unit
description: A density unit which is a standard measure of the mass exerting an influence on a given area.

nodes.name: linear density unit
description: A density unit which is a standard measure of the mass exerting an influence on a one-dimensional object.

nodes.name: molar volume unit
description: A unit which is a standard measure of the volume of a homogeneous substance containing 6.02 x 1023 atoms or molecules.

nodes.name: specific volume unit
description: A unit which is a standard measure of the volume of a given mass of substance (the reciprocal of density).

nodes.name: cubic meter
description: A volume unit which is equal to the volume of a cube with edges one meter in length. One cubic meter equals to 1000 liters.

nodes.name: cubic centimeter
description: A volume unit which is equal to one millionth of a cubic meter or 10^[-9] m^[3], or to 1 ml.

nodes.name: milliliter
description: A volume unit which is equal to one thousandth of a liter or 10^[-3] L, or to 1 cubic centimeter.

nodes.name: liter
description: A volume unit which is equal to one thousandth of a cubic meter or 10^[-3] m^[3], or to 1 decimeter.

nodes.name: cubic decimeter
description: A volume unit which is equal to one thousand of a cubic meter or 10^[-3] m^[3], or to 1 L.

nodes.name: microliter
description: A volume unit which is equal to one millionth of a liter or 10^[-6] L.

nodes.name: nanoliter
description: A volume unit which is equal to one thousandth of one millionth of a liter or 10^[-9] L.

nodes.name: picoliter
description: A volume unit which is equal to 10^[-12] L.

nodes.name: femtoliter
description: A volume unit which is equal to 10^[-15] L.

nodes.name: deciliter
description: A volume unit which is equal to one tenth of a liter or 10^[-1] L.

nodes.name: fluid ounce
description: An imperial volume unit which is equivalent to 28.413,0625 millilitres.

nodes.name: gill
description: An imperial volume unit which is equivalent to 142.065,3125 millilitres.

nodes.name: pint
description: An imperial volume unit which is equivalent to 568.261,25 millilitres.

nodes.name: quart
description: An imperial volume unit which is equivalent to 1,136.5225 millilitres, or two pints.

nodes.name: gallon
description: An imperial volume unit which is equivalent to 4,546.09 millilitres, or 8 pints.

nodes.name: teaspoon
description: A metric teaspoon is a unit of measurement of volume widely used in cooking recipes and pharmaceutic prescriptions. It equals a 5mL volume.

nodes.name: united states customary teaspoon
description: A United States customary units teaspoon is a unit of measurement of volume widely used in cooking recipes and pharmaceutic prescriptions in America. It equals a 4.93 mL volume.

nodes.name: tablespoon
description: A metric tablespoon is a unit of measurement of volume widely used in cooking recipes and pharmaceutic prescriptions. It equals a 15mL volume.

nodes.name: australian metric tablespoon
description: An Australian metric tablespoon is a unit of measurement of volume used in Australia for cooking recipes and pharmaceutic prescriptions. It equals a 20mL volume.

nodes.name: united states customary tablespoon
description: A United States customary units tablespoon is a unit of measurement of volume widely used in cooking recipes and pharmaceutic prescriptions in America. It equals a 14.79 mL volume.

nodes.name: metric cup
description: A metric cup is a unit of measurement of volume widely used in cooking recipes and pharmaceutic prescriptions. It equals a 250mL volume.

nodes.name: united states customary cup
description: A United States customary units cup is a unit of measurement of volume widely used in cooking recipes and pharmaceutic prescriptions in America. It equals a 236.59 mL volume.

nodes.name: united states fda cup
description: A United States FDA cup is a unit of measurement of volume used by the US Federal Department of Agriculture as a nutritional serving measure. It equals a 240 mL volume.

nodes.name: rotational frequency unit
description: A unit which is a standard measure of the number of rotations in a given time.

nodes.name: hertz
description: A frequency unit which is equal to 1 complete cycle of a recurring phenomenon in 1 second.

nodes.name: megaHertz
description: A frequency unit which is equal to one million hertz or 10^[6] V.

nodes.name: unit of molarity
description: A concentration unit which is a standard measure of the number of moles of a given substance per liter of solution.

nodes.name: unit of molality
description: A concentration unit which is a standard measure of the number of moles of a given substance per kilogram of solvent.

nodes.name: unit of normality
description: A unit of concentration which highlights the chemical nature of salts.

nodes.name: mole fraction
description: A concentration unit which denotes the number of moles of solute as a proportion of the total number of moles in a solution.

nodes.name: mass percentage
description: A dimensionless concentration unit which denotes the mass of a substance in a mixture as a percentage of the mass of the entire mixture.

nodes.name: mass volume percentage
description: A dimensionless concentration unit which denotes the mass of the substance in a mixture as a percentage of the volume of the entire mixture.

nodes.name: unit per volume unit
description: A concentration unit which is a standard measure of the number of units, as an agreed arbitrary amount, of a given substance per a specific volume of solution.

nodes.name: mass per unit volume
description: A concentration unit which is a standard measure of the mass of a substance in a given volume (density).

nodes.name: pH
description: A dimensionless concentration notation which denotes the acidity of a solution in terms of activity of hydrogen ions (H+).

nodes.name: cell concentration unit
description: A concentration unit which denotes the average cell number in a given volume.

nodes.name: catalytic (activity) concentration unit
description: A concentration unit which is a standard measure of the amount of the action of a catalyst in a given volume.

nodes.name: volume per unit volume
description: A dimensionless concentration unit which denotes the given volume of the solute in the total volume of the resulting solution.

nodes.name: colony forming unit per volume
description: A concentration unit which a measure of viable bacterial numbers in a given volume.

nodes.name: plaque forming unit per volume
description: A concentration unit which a measure of plague forming units in a given volume.

nodes.name: amount per container
description: A concentration unit which is a standard measure of the amount of a substance in a given container.

nodes.name: dose unit
description: A concentration unit which is a standard measure of the amount of a toxic or pharmaceutical substance administered to a recipient subject, expressed in terms of the size of the subject.

nodes.name: dosage unit
description: A concentration unit which is a standard measure of the amount of a toxic or pharmaceutical substance administered over time to a recipient subject, expressed in terms of the size of the subject.

nodes.name: radioactivity concentration
description: A concentration unit which is a standard measure of the amount of radioactivity in a given volume.

nodes.name: molar
description: A unit of concentration which expresses a concentration of 1 mole of solute per liter of solution (mol/L).

nodes.name: millimolar
description: A unit of molarity which is equal to one thousandth of a molar or 10^[-3] M.

nodes.name: micromolar
description: A unit of molarity which is equal to one millionth of a molar or 10^[-6] M.

nodes.name: nanomolar
description: A unit of molarity which is equal to one thousandth of one millionth of a molar or 10^[-9] M.

nodes.name: picomolar
description: A unit of molarity which is equal to 10^[-12] M.

nodes.name: femtomolar
description: A unit of molarity which is equal to 10^[-15] M.

nodes.name: molal
description: A unit of concentration which expresses a concentration of a solution of 1 mole per kilogram of solvent (mol/kg).

nodes.name: millimolal
description: A molality unit which is equal to one thousandth of a molal or 10^[-3] m.

nodes.name: micromolal
description: A molality unit which is equal to one millionth of a molal or 10^[-6] m.

nodes.name: nanomolal
description: A molality unit which is equal to one thousandth of one millionth of a molal or 10^[-9] m.

nodes.name: picomolal
description: A molality unit which is equal to 10^[-12] m.

nodes.name: micromole per litre
description: A specific concentration unit which is equal to 1 micromole in a given volume of one thousandth of a cubic meter.

nodes.name: micromole per kilogram
description: A specific concentration unit which is equal to 1 micromole of a given substance per kilogram of solvent.

nodes.name: normal
description: A unit of concentration which is one gram equivalent of a solute per liter of solution. A gram equivalent weight or equivalent is a measure of the reactive capacity of a given molecule.

nodes.name: fraction
description: A dimensionless ratio unit which relates the part (the numerator) to the whole (the denominator).

nodes.name: meter per second per second
description: An acceleration unit which is equal to the acceleration an object changing its velocity by 1meter/s over a time period that equals one second.

nodes.name: radian per second per second
description: An angular unit acceleration which is equal to the angular acceleration of an object changing its angular velocity by 1rad/s over a time period that equals one second.

nodes.name: radian per second
description: An angular unit velocity which is equal to about 9.54930 rpm (revolutions per minute).

nodes.name: kilogram per cubic meter
description: A mass unit density which is equal to mass of an object in kilograms divided by the volume in cubic meters.

nodes.name: gram per cubic centimeter
description: A mass unit density which is equal to mass of an object in grams divided by the volume in cubic centimeters.

nodes.name: gram per milliliter
description: A mass unit density which is equal to mass of an object in grams divided by the volume in milliliter.

nodes.name: kilogram per liter
description: A mass unit density which is equal to mass of an object in kilograms divided by the volume in liters.

nodes.name: gram per liter
description: A mass unit density which is equal to mass of an object in grams divided by the volume in liters.

nodes.name: milligram per milliliter
description: A mass unit density which is equal to mass of an object in milligrams divided by the volume in milliliters.

nodes.name: gram per deciliter
description: A mass density unit which is equal to mass of an object in grams divided by the volume in deciliters.

nodes.name: milligram per liter
description: A mass unit density which is equal to mass of an object in milligrams divided by the volume in liters.

nodes.name: microgram per milliliter
description: A mass unit density which is equal to mass of an object in micrograms divided by the volume in millliters.

nodes.name: nanogram per milliliter
description: A mass unit density which is equal to mass of an object in nanograms divided by the volume in milliliters.

nodes.name: microgram per liter
description: A mass unit density which is equal to mass of an object in micrograms divided by the volume in liters.

nodes.name: candela per square meter
description: A luminance unit which is equal to a luminous intensity of one candela radiating from a surface whose area is one square meter.

nodes.name: kilogram per square meter
description: An area density unit which is equal to the mass of an object in kilograms divided by the surface area in meters squared.

nodes.name: kilogram per hectare
description: An area density unit which is equal to the mass of an object in kilograms divided by the surface area in hectares.

nodes.name: ton per hectare
description: An area density unit which is equal to the mass of an object in tons divided by the surface area in hectares.

nodes.name: kilogram per mole
description: A molar mass unit which is equal to one kilogram of mass of one mole of chemical element or chemical compound.

nodes.name: gram per mole
description: A molar mass unit which is equal to one gram of mass of one mole of chemical element or chemical compound.

nodes.name: cubic meter per mole
description: A molar volume unit which is equal to 1 cubic meter occupied by one mole of a substance in the form of a solid, liquid, or gas.

nodes.name: cubic centimeter per mole
description: A molar volume unit which is equal to 1 cubic centimeter occupied by one mole of a substance in the form of a solid, liquid, or gas.

nodes.name: kilogram meter per second
description: A momentum unit which is equal to the momentum of a one kilogram mass object with a speed of one meter per second.

nodes.name: turns per second
description: A rotational frequency unit which is equal to the number complete turn in a period of time that equals to 1 second.

nodes.name: cubic meter per kilogram
